name: ballMVP
probTex: Prove that a harmonic function $u$ on $\Omega$ satisfies the mean value property, which we rename the circle mean value property. Prove also that $u$ satisfies the ball mean value property that for all $a\in\Omega$ and all $r>0$ small enough that $\overline{B_r(a)}\subset\Omega$\n\[u(a)=\frac{1}{\pi r^2}\iint_{B_r(a)}u(x+iy)dxdy.\]
solnTex:
By choice of $a,r$ there is a simply connected open subset of $\Omega$ which contains $\overline{B_r(a)}$. Take a harmonic conjugate $v$ on this neighborhood to obtain the holomorphic function $f=u+iv$. Recall Cauchy's integral formula,
\[f(a)= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{|z-a|=r} rac{f(z)}{z-a}dz.\]
Restating with $u$ and $v$ gives
\[u(a)+iv(a)= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_0^{2\pi} rac{u(a+re^{it})+iv(a+re^{it})}{re^{it}}ire^{it}dt= rac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}u(a+re^{it})+iv(a+re^{it})dt.\]
The real part of the above equation is the circle mean value property.
Let $0<s<r$. Because $u$ satisfies the circle mean value property,
\[u(a)= rac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}u(a+se^{i	heta})d	heta.\]
Scale both sides by $s$.
\[2\pi su(a)=\int_0^{2\pi}u(a+se^{i	heta})sd	heta.\]
Integrate both sides with respect to $s$ from $0$ to $r$.
\[\pi r^2u(a)=\int_0^r\int_0^{2\pi}u(a+se^{i	heta})sd	heta ds=\iint_{B_r(a)}u(x+iy)dxdy.\]
